user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static int irq_notify_fd
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__;\
})
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment is a macro that uses its parameters (level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) but does not assign to or otherwise modify them. Rule 17.8 concerns modification of function parameters (and pointer parameters themselves); here no function parameter is being modified, and macro parameters are only read/expanded, so the rule is not violated.
